children.name: to know a fact or piece of info
know
children.definition: /nəʊ/  to know a fact or piece of information in your mind :biết
examples: ▪ I love this painting - do you know the name of the artist?
▪ Jack’s leaving. Didn’t you know?

children.name: know (that)
examples: ▪ I knew he was ill, but I didn’t realize he had cancer.

children.name: know how/what/where etc
examples: ▪ Do you know where Andy is?

children.name: know about
examples: ▪ How much do you know about the Moore case?

children.name: know of
examples: ▪ I know of one company where members of staff get their meals free.

children.name: know a lot about
examples: ▪ He knew a lot about baseball, and about how to pick great players.

children.name: can tell
children.definition: especiallyspokento know that something istruebecause you can seesignsthat show this: có thể nói
examples: ▪ She’s going to have a baby - couldn’t you tell?

children.name: can tell (that)
examples: ▪ I could tell he worked outdoors, because he had a deep tan.

children.name: can tell by/from
examples: ▪ You can tell by the look on her face that she’s hiding something.

children.name: can tell whether/what/how etc
examples: ▪ You can tell when kids aren’t feeling well.
▪ I couldn’t tell exactly how old he was.
from what I can tell...
▪ Don’t worry. From what I can tell, you’ll make a great father.

children.name: know perfectly well
children.definition: /nəʊ ˌpɜːʳfɪktli ˈwel/  spoken use this to say that someone knows something, although they behave as if they do not: biết quá rõ, hiểu quá rõ

children.name: know perfectly well (that)
examples: ▪ He knows perfectly well, he’s not allowed to park outside the main door.
▪ I knew perfectly well that I had anorexia, but I wouldn’t admit that it was a problem.

children.name: know perfectly well what/why/who etc
examples: ▪ You know perfectly well what I mean, so stop pretending you don’t.

children.name: know from experience
children.definition: know/learn from experience/ˌnəʊ, ˌlɜːʳn frəm ɪkˈspɪəriəns/  to know what islikely to happenin a particular situation, because you have learned from your own experiences: theo kinh nghiệm đã biết

children.name: know/learn from experience (that)
examples: ▪ He knew from experience that most ship’s captains were not adequately covered with life insurance.

children.name: know from past/personal/first-hand etc experience
examples: ▪ Kelly knew from personal experience that education is a ticket out of minimum-wage work.

children.name: know from bitter experienceknow something because of a bad experience of something similar rút từ kinh nghiệm xương máu
examples: ▪ Sue learned from bitter experience not to rely on Martin in times of crisis.

children.name: to know a place, a film, a book etc
be familiar with sth
children.definition: be familiar with to know a thing or place well because you have seen it, read it, used it, or been there: biết đến
examples: ▪ Are you familiar with this type of software?
▪ I grew up near Lake George, so I’m very familiar with the towns around there.
▪ Are you familiar with the works of George Eliot?

children.name: know
children.definition: if you know a place, you have been there before and spent time there; if you know a book, song, film etc, you have read it or seen it or heard it before: biết
examples: ▪ ‘Do you know Boston at all?’ ‘Yes, I went to college there.’
▪ I didn’t know any of the songs they were singing.
▪ Do you know that Hitchcock movie about a man who is being chased?
know sth by heart: thuộc lòng
know every word of a song, poem etc without having to read it
▪ The congregation seemed to know all the hymns by heart.
know swh like the back of your handinformal know a place very well nắm trong lòng bàn tay
▪ Tony had spent a lot of time in Tokyo and knew the place like the back of his hand.

children.name: be acquainted with
children.definition: formal to know something: biết đến
examples: ▪ I was not acquainted with the north-western part of the island.
▪ Through art, children become acquainted with cultures other than their own.

children.name: be fully acquainted with
examples: ▪ All our employees are fully acquainted with the safety procedures.

children.name: to feel sure sth is true even though you have no proof
feel
children.definition: cảm thấy
examples: ▪ I felt a definite sense of danger and impending disaster.

children.name: feel (that)
examples: ▪ I always felt I had the ability to become a reasonable actor.
▪ It is a common experience to feel that an author writes well without being able to say exactly why.

children.name: sense
children.definition: /sens/  to feel that something is present or is happening where you are although you cannot see or hear anything to prove it: cảm nhận, cảm thấy
examples: ▪ We could sense an unwelcoming atmosphere.
▪ I wasn’t that thrilled with her performance, and I’m sure she sensed it.

children.name: sense (that)
examples: ▪ After a while, I sensed that he was no longer listening.

children.name: know
children.definition: to feel very strongly that sth is true: biết
examples: ▪ Everyone knew immediately how serious the situation was.

children.name: know (that)
examples: ▪ I knew that this was going to happen.
▪ I know damn well she won’t keep her promise.

children.name: just know
examples: ▪ I knew it was a huge gamble, buying the stuff without seeing it, but I just knew it would be good quality.

children.name: have a feeling
children.definition: /get the feeling to feel almost sure that something is true, although you have no proof:có cảm giác

children.name: have a feeling/get the feeling (that)
examples: ▪ As we walked along together, I had a feeling that we were both thinking the same thing.
▪ Maybe we should leave him alone. I have a feeling he doesn’t want us here.

children.name: well known
children.definition: use this aboutfactsandideasthat most people know about, or that all the people in a particular group know about:được biết đến
examples: ▪ Her views on the single European currency were well known.

children.name: it is well known that
examples: ▪ It is well known that people who smoke are more likely to get lung diseases.
▪ It was well known that Mr. Walters was interested in our mother.

children.name: everyone knows
children.definition: especiallyspokensay this when you think most people know sth and you would be surprised if someone did not know it: ai cũng biết
examples: ▪ Haven’t you heard Anja’s pregnant? I thought everyone knew.

children.name: everyone knows (that)
examples: ▪ Everyone knows that for a democracy to truly work, everyone has to get involved in some way.

children.name: everyone knows how/what/why etc
examples: ▪ Surely everyone knows how to change a light bulb!

children.name: be common knowledge
children.definition: if informationaboutsbis common knowledge, a lot of people know about it, even when that person would prefer to keep it a secret: là hiểu biết thông thường
examples: It’s common knowledge here in Miami that this whole operation was paid for with cocaine money.

children.name: be common knowledge that
examples: It’s already common knowledge that their marriage is breaking up.
It's common knowledge that they live together.

children.name: be no secret
children.definition: if an unpleasant fact is no secret, everyone knows about it: ko phải bí mật gì
examples: ▪ Everyone knows they hate each other, it’s no secret.

children.name: be no secret that
examples: ▪ It was no secret that Morrison was with the CIA, but nobody knew exactly what he did.

children.name: be an open secret
children.definition: if sth is an open secret, it is supposed to be secret but most people know about it: điều bí mật mà ai cũng biết
examples: ▪ Her relationship with a French millionaire is pretty much an open secret around here.

children.name: be an open secret that
examples: ▪ It’s an open secret that organized crime has been financing films here for years.

children.name: freedom of information
children.definition: when a government allows people to know what is in official government records, documents etc: tự do thông tin
examples: Freedom of information should be a basic right in a democracy.

children.name: to know a lot about sth
know about
children.definition: know (all) about
examples: ▪ My brother knows about cars. I’m sure he could fix it for you.
▪ You can’t become an architect unless you know all about building regulations.

children.name: know a lot about sth
examples: ▪ The old man knew a lot about the history of the village.

children.name: know all there is to knowaboutsthto know everything about a particular subject
examples: ▪ I thought I knew all there was to know about men, until I met Jason.

children.name: be well versed in
children.definition: to know a lot about a particular subject because you have had a lot of experience of it: sành, thông thạo
examples: ▪ The new prime minister is well versed in economic policy.
▪ Victor Amadeus was reputed to be well versed in poisons and their antidotes.

children.name: know sth inside out
children.definition: know sth inside (and) out informal to know a particular subject verythoroughly: hiểu rõ, rành, biết từ trong ra ngoài
examples: ▪ She’s very experienced -- she knows the advertising business inside out.
▪You need to know your specialized subject inside and out.
_He knows the system inside out.

children.name: be clued up
children.definition: UK informal to know all the facts that you need to know about a subject, especially because you have found it out before you start doing sth: tìm hiểu hết

children.name: be clued up on/ about
examples: ▪ Are you clued up on what points to look for when buying a used car?
▪ We’d better get clued up about this new computer system before we start using it.

children.name: specialize in
children.definition: specialize/ specialiseUK

children.name: specialize in/ specialise inUK to know a lot about one particular subject or activity because you study it or do it more than any other: chuyên về
examples: My history professor specialized in Russian history.
The chef specializes in Hunan and Szechuan cuisine, but all the dishes we tried were delicious.
She's hired a lawyer who specializesindivorce cases.

children.name: a restaurant that specializesinseafood
examples: I enjoy working in general medicine, but I hope to be able to specialize in the future.

children.name: know what you are talking about
children.definition: /ˌnəʊ wɒt juː ɑːʳ ˈtɔːkɪŋ əbaʊt/  informal to know a lot about a particular subject so that your judgement can be trusted, especially because you have had a lot ofexperience:hiểu bản thân đang nói gì
examples: ▪ Pilger knows what he is talking about, having spent several years as a reporter in Vietnam.
▪ Rolim seemed to know what he was talking about, but his theories raised some questions for me.
He doesn't know what he's talking about-he's never even been to Africa.

children.name: knowledgeable
children.definition: sb who is knowledgeable knows a lot of different facts, especially about aparticularsubjectoractivity: có nhiều kiến thức
examples: The sales staff are all knowledgeable, helpful, and cheerful.
Visitors should use reputable travel firms with knowledgeable guides, and avoid camping alone.

children.name: knowledgeable about/in
examples: We are looking for people who are knowledgeable about the oil and banking industries.
Earley is a diligent reporter, knowledgeable in the field of espionage.
He's very knowledgeable about German literature.
Gradually the band became more knowledgeable about the business dealings in the music industry.

children.name: well-informed
children.definition: knowing a lot about one particular subject or about many subjects : thạo tin, thông thạo
examples: "Le Monde' is a newspaper designed for well-informed readers.
According to one well-informed source, the two sides are very near to reaching an agreement.
We had a serious and well-informed debate.

children.name: well-informed about
examples: Most people are not very well-informed about the disease.
Abdul Karim was particularly well- informed about American politics.

children.name: be a mine of information
children.definition: to know a lot about a particular subject or about various subjects, so that you are usually able to answer anything that people ask you: nguồn tin tức
examples: The British Ambassador proved to be a mine of information on the subject of the Royal Family.

children.name: be well up on
children.definition: UK /be up onUS  spoken to know a lot about sth, including the most recent information: cập nhật thông tin
examples: How well up are you on men’s fashion?
Don’t ask me - I’m not really up on current events in that part of the world.

children.name: have your finger on the pulse
children.definition: to always know what changes and developments are happening in a particular situation or organization:nắm rõ tình hình
examples: The situation changes daily, so you've got to keep your finger on the pulse.

children.name: have your finger on the pulse of
examples: As a manager of a bookshop, I have to have my finger on the pulse of the publishing industry.

children.name: keep abreast of
children.definition: / keep up to date with to make sure that you know all the most recent news about what is happening somewhere or about new developments in a particular subject: cập nhật
examples: When we lived abroad, we always kept abreast of what was happening at home.
It’s very important for students to keep up to date with developments in their own field of study.

children.name: to know a little about sth
know a little about
children.definition: know a little (bit) about/ know a bit aboutespecially UK  biết một chút về
examples: ▪ This excellent book can be understood by anyone who knows a little about social anthropology.
▪ I know a bit about how psychiatry works, having been in therapy for years.

children.name: have a smattering of
children.definition: to have only a small amount of knowledge about a subject, especially of a foreign language: có biết chút về, lõm bõm
examples: ▪ He only has a smattering of English, so it can be quite difficult trying to communicate with him.
▪ I left school with no more than a smattering of scientific knowledge.

children.name: have a working knowledge of
children.definition: to have enough knowledge of sth such as a system or a foreign language to be able to use it, although your knowledge is limited: biết chút ít về (đủ xài)
examples: You don’t need to be an expert, but we do expect you to have a good working knowledge of computers.
For the system to work, mediators must have a working knowledge of the law.

children.name: can get by
children.definition: /be able to get byspokento know justenoughabout sth, for example a foreign language, to be able to make yourself understood or do sth successfully:biết vừa đủ xài về
examples: ▪ My Spanish isn’t great, but I can get by as a tourist.
can get by/be able to get by on/with
▪ ‘Can I still pass the course?’ ‘You may be able to get by on what you’ve already read.’

children.name: to know sth most people don't know
be in the know
children.definition: to know secret information about sth, for example a government plan or sb’s private life, that only a small group of people know: nắm thông tin nguồn
examples: I heard it from someone who’s in the know, so it must be true.
Those who were in the know bought land where the railway was to be built, and made enormous profits.
The people in the know are saying that the team doesn’t have enough money to keep Wojek for another season.

children.name: be in on
children.definition: informalto know about asecretplan or activity that only a small group of people know about, especially when you areinvolvedin it:biết về (bí mật, tham gia vào)
examples: The children are planning a surprise for Grandma. Are you in on this?
It turned out that some of the local cops were in on the deal too.

children.name: let sb in on sthtell them about a secret nói cho ai đó nghe về cái gì một cách bí mật
examples: We made the mistake of letting my sister in on the plan, and she, of course, told my parents.

children.name: be privy to
children.definition: especially written to know about sth that is kept a secret from most people, especially because sb trusts you enough to tell you about it: biết bí mật, riêng tư
examples: She became a confidante of Churchill, and thus was privy to some of his thinking.
The Division was not privy to all the information being collected in Saigon.

children.name: knowing
children.definition: look/smile/wink etc a look, smile etcthat shows that you know sth that other people do not know or that you share a secret with someone:
examples: I saw him give her a knowing smile as she left the room.
Her questions and knowing looks unnerved him, almost as if she had figured him out.

children.name: to know the most recent info about sth
be in touch
children.definition: be/keep/stay etc in touch (with sth)to have the latest knowledge about a subject, situation, or the way people feel
examples: A regular newsletter keeps people in touch with local events.
The speech was good and you felt he was in touch with people’s needs.
Rescuers were kept in touch through radio links.
A head-teacher needs to remainin close touch withteachers’ everyday concerns.
He's not really in touch with what young people are interested in.
I didn't look at a newspaper all the time I was on holiday, so I'm completely out of touch.

children.name: know of
children.definition: sb/sthphrasal verbmainly UKbiết

children.name: to haveheard of someone or somethingand be able to give a small amount ofinformation about them
examples: _Do you know of a good doctor?

children.name: be on the ball
children.definition: to be quick to understand and react to things
examples: _I didn't sleep well last night and I'm not really on the ball today.

children.name: keep sb in the picture
children.definition: keepsbin the picture
examples: to make sure someone knows all the facts about a changing situation
_I use the radio to keep me in the picture about what's happening abroad.
putsbin the picture
to tell someone the facts about a situation
_His lawyer put him in the picture
about what had happened since his arrest.

children.name: literate
children.definition: having knowledge of a particular subject, or a particular type of knowledge : biết
examples: computer literate/musically literate etc

children.name: illiterate
children.definition: knowing little or nothing about a particular subject
examples: economically/politically/scientifically etc illiterate

children.name: known
children.definition: adjective
examples: describes something or someonethat is familiar to or understood by people
_These people are known criminals. ( nhung nguoi nay nhung ke fam toi quen thuoc )
_There is no known reason for the accident.( chang co ly do nao duoc biet ve vu tai nan )
_He is knowntothe police because of his previous criminal record.
( anh ay thi quen thuoc voi canh sat vi ho so toi fam cua anh ta truoc do )

children.name: hear of
children.definition: sb/sthphrasal verb nghe nóive

children.name: If you have heard of someone or something, you know that that person or thing exists
examples: _I'd never heard of him before he won the prize.
_It's a tiny country that most people have never heard of.

children.name: know best
children.definition: to be the most suitable personto have responsibility and make important decisions
examples: _When it comes to dealing with my own son, I think I know best.

children.name: know better
children.definition: (than to dosth)

children.name: to be wise or moral enough not to do something
examples: _Sure, she's only six, but she'sold enough toknow better than to run off without us.
_I'm surprised at you behaving so badly youought to/shouldknow better.
